questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, backache, contractions, and show. She is a case of mitral stenosis due to RHD and is on treatment. Abdominal examination shows fundus just below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min, contractions of 3/10mins. PV examination shows cervix soft, dilated 3cm, 2cm long, head at station 0, membranes intact. NST was normal. Consider the following statements about the prognosis of such cases. The true statement is /are: 1. Maternal mortality is low in Rheumatic heart disease and a cyanotic heart disease 2. Most deaths occur due to cardiac failure 3. Maximum deaths occur following birth 4. Prognosis depends on the nature of the lesion and the functional capacity of the heart Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The clinical case scenario is heart disease – Mitral stenosis due to RHD in pregnancy. Point 1 Maternal mortality is lowest in rheumatic heart lesions and a cyanotic group of heart diseases—less than 1 percent. With an elevation of pulmonary vascular resistance, especially with cyanotic heart lesions, the mortality may be increased to even 50 percent (Eisenmenger’s syndrome). Points 2 and 3 Most deaths occur due to cardiac failure, and the maximum number of deaths occur following birth . The other causes of death are—(a) pulmonary edema, (b) pulmonary embolism, (c) active rheumatic carditis, (d) subacute bacterial endocarditis, and (e) rupture of cerebral aneurysm in coarctation of the However, with improved medical care, surgical correction of congenital lesions, and better obstetric care, maternal mortality has been reduced markedly. Pregnancy, however, does not affect the long-term survival of a woman with a rheumatic heart lesion, provided she survives pregnancy itself. Point 4 MATERNAL : The prognosis depends on (1) the Nature of the lesion, (2) the Functional capacity of the heart, (3) the Quality of medical supervision provided during pregnancy, labor, and the puerperium (4) the Presence of other risk factors mentioned earlier (5) Whether the patient has undergone corrective surgery or not.

Highyeild:

PROGNOSIS ♦ Maternal ♦ Fetal MATERNAL: The prognosis depends on: (1) Nature of lesion (2) Functional capacity of the heart (3) Quality of medical supervision provided during pregnancy, labor and puerperium (4) Presence of other risk factors mentioned earlier (5) Whether patient has undergone corrective surgery or not. Maternal mortality is lowest in rheumatic heart lesions and acyanotic group of heart diseases-less than 1%. With elevation of pulmonary vascular resistance especially with cyanotic heart lesions, the mortality may be raised to even 50% (Eisenmenger's syndrome). Most of the deaths occur due to cardiac failure and the maximum deaths occur following birth. T he other causes of death are- (a) pulmonary edema (b) pulmonary embolism (c) active rheumatic carditis (d) subacute bacterial endocarditis and (e) rupture of cerebral aneurysm in coarctation of aorta. However, with improved medical care, surgical correction of the congenital lesions and better obstetric care, the maternal mortality has been reduced markedly. Pregnancy however, does not affect the long- term survival of a woman with rheumatic heart lesion provided she survives pregnancy itself. FETAL: In rheumatic heart lesions, the fetal outcome is usually good and in no way different from the patients without any heart lesion. However, in cyanotic group of heart lesion, there is increased fetal loss (45%) due to abortion, IUGR and prematurity. Fetal congenital cardiac disease is increased by 3-10% if either of the parents have congenital lesions.

questions.text: A 24-Year-old G3A2 with 33 weeks of gestation presents a history of generalized weakness, exertional breathlessness, and chest discomfort. She says she has difficulty performing her daily chores but feels better after rest. She has valvular defects due to Rheumatic heart disease and is treated for the same. On examination, P-90/min, BP-120/84mmHg, RR-12/min, afebrile, saturation-95 percent, pallor +, B/L pedal edema upto ankle seen. Abdominal examination shows in-between fundus umbilicus and xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. The NYHA grade to which the female belongs is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade 3 The given clinical case scenario is that of Rheumatic heart disease in pregnancy. The clinical description points towards markedly compromised and limitation of activity due to heart disease. Hence it is classified under Grade 3 according to NYHA.

Highyeild:

New York Heart Association (NYHA) Classification of Heart Disease (Depending Upon the Cardiac Response to Physical Activity) Grade-1: Uncompromised and no limitation of physical activity Grade II: Slightly compromised with slight regulation of physical activity. The patients are comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes discomfort Grade III: Markedly compromised with marked limitation of movement. The patients are satisfied at rest, but pain occurs with less-than-normal activity Grade IV: Severely compromised with pain even at rest Limitation: This classification has considered the symptoms only but not the anatomical type and severity of pathology . It does not predict pregnancy outcomes.

Extraedge:

Antepartum Management Time of hospitalisation: Class I of NYHA - 36 weeks Class II 28 weeks Class III and IV - If seen in the first trimester . MTP should be advised ideally, but if the patient wants to continue the pregnancy, the woman is hospitalized for the remainder. Remember: In India, MTP usually is legal for up to 20 weeks, but in heart disease patients, MTP should not be done at 12 weeks as after 12 weeks, the risk involved with delivery and abortion are the same. bo

questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation presents with a history of generalized weakness, chest pain, difficulty carrying out everyday chores, and exertional breathlessness. She has no comorbidities. She was admitted, progressed to labor, and had a normal vaginal delivery with episiotomy. The neonate weighed 2.5 kg and was normal. Her saturation dropped to 88 percent. She developed severe chest pain and breathlessness post-delivery. ECG and 2D ECHO were done, and there were signs of heart failure and cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction- of 40 percent. The criteria to consider her as a case of peripartum cardiomyopathy are: 1. Ejection fraction < 45 percent 2. Cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or < 5 months postpartum 3. No history of previous cardiac disease 4. No determinable cause for failure Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The given clinical scenario points towards peripartum cardiomyopathy. Peripartum cardiomyopathy : Important diagnostic criteria are: (i) Cardiac failure within the last month of pregnancy or five months postpartum. (ii) No determinable cause for failure. (iii) Absence of previous heart disease. (iv) Left ventricular dysfunction as evidenced by echocardiography—(a) Ejection fraction less than 45 percent and (b) Left ventricular end-diastolic dimension more than 2.7 cm/m2. Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a diagnosis of exclusion. The patients are usually multiparous and young (20–35 years). They complain of weakness, shortness of breath, cough, nocturnal dyspnoea, and pulse. Examination reveals—tachycardia, arrhythmia, peripheral edema, and pulmonary rales. Pregnancy is poorly tolerated in women with dilated cardiomyopathy. MANAGEMENT: The treatment is bed rest, digoxin, diuretics (preload reduction), hydralazine or ACE inhibitors (postpartum) (afterload reduction), beta blocker, and anticoagulant therapy. Vaginal delivery is preferred. Epidural anesthesia is ideal. There is no contraindication to breastfeeding. Mortality is high (20–50 percent)—due to CCF, arrhythmia, or thromboembolism. It may recur in subsequent pregnancies.

Highyeild:

Anatomical and Physiological Changes During Pregnancy that Mimic Cardiac Disease Hyperdynamic circulation Systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the aortic and pulmonary valves) Dyspnea, decreased exercise tolerance, fatigue, syncope Tachycardia, the shift of ventricular apex Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space- mammary souffle Loud first sound with splitting Symptoms must be carefully assessed, and investigations are to be done to confirm the diagnosis.

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 32-Year-old G3A1P1 with 26 weeks of gestation presents with a history of increased generalized weakness, palpitations, swelling of lower limbs, and occasional chest pain. She has no comorbidities. She is on iron and calcium tablets. Her first-trimester use and lab reports are normal. On examination, P - 80bpm, BP- 138/ 88mmHg, afebrile, saturation normal, RR-12/min, pallor +, B/L pedal edema + upto ankle. NST is normal. ECG was done and showed left ventricular hypertrophy. 2D ECHO was advised. The most common cardiac lesion seen in most pregnancies is -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rheumatic fever The given clinical case scenario points towards heart disease in pregnancy. INCIDENCE AND TYPES: The incidence of cardiac lesions is less than 1 percent amongst hospital deliveries. Most joint cardiac lesions are rheumatic, followed by congenital ones. The ratio has fallen over the past two decades from 10: 1 to about 3: 1 or even 1: 1 in advanced countries—adequate treatment of rheumatic fever by appropriate antibiotics to cope with the group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection. Rheumatic valvular lesion predominantly includes mitral stenosis (80 percent). Predominant congenital lesions include patent ductus arteriosus, atrial or ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, coarctation of the aorta, and Fallot’s tetralogy. Rare causes are hypertensive, thyrotoxic, syphilitic, or coronary cardiac diseases.

questions.text: A prosthetic valve patient switches to heparin at which time of pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

36 weeks Management of High-Risk Pregnancy Pregnancy following valve replacement: Mechanical valve replacement is not preferred these days as anticoagulation is required throughout pregnancy. Warfarin is safe for the mother but can result in warfarin embryopathy of the fetus, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin in preventing thromboembolic events. Low molecular weight heparin is inadequate, and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Highyeild:

Anticoagulants are indicated in cases with (a) Congenital heart disease, (b) pulmonary hypertension, (c) mechanical heart valve, and (d) atrial fibrillation. The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it (see p. 510) as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) can also be used. This is then replaced by warfarin tablet 3 mg. daily to be taken simultaneously each day and continued up to 36 weeks. After that, it is replaced by heparin up to 7 days postpartum. Warfarin is then to be continued. UFH, LMWH, and Warfarin therapy do not contraindicate breastfeeding.

Extraedge:

Warfarin embryopathy results in bone and cartilaginous abnormalities with chondrodysplasia, nasal hypoplasia, optic atrophy, microphthalmia, blindness, minor neurologic dysfunction, reduced intelligence quotient, and seizures. Warfarin does not enter the breast milk and thus can be administered safely to women who breast-feed infants .

questions.text: In which of the following heart diseases is maternal mortality highest?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eisenmenger's complex Eisenmenger’s syndrome is the presence of secondary pulmonary hypertension that develops from any cardiac lesion. The syndrome develops when increased pulmonary blood flow due to the left to right shunt produces a proper side pressure more than the left side and hence reversal of the shunt occurs, and subsequently, cyanosis develops. It is the heart disease with the worst prognosis during pregnancy, with a maternal mortality of 50% . Hence, pregnancy is contraindicated in patients of Eisenmenger's. If an Eisenmenger is diagnosed in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised . The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: The maximum strain of the parturient heart occurs during?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate postpartum Significant hemodynamic alterations are apparent early in pregnancy; women with severe cardiac dysfunction may experience worsening of heart failure before mid- In others, heart failure develops after 28 weeks, when pregnancy-induced hypervolemia is maximal (32 weeks). In the majority, however, heart failure develops peripartum when the physiological capability for rapid changes in cardiac output may be overwhelmed in the presence of structural cardiac disease. It is clear that the maximum chances of heart failure are in the peripartum period. But it is unclear whether the maximum chances are during labor or immediate postpartum. The cardiac output starts to increase from the 5th week of pregnancy, and reaches its peak of 40-50% at about 30-34 weeks. After that, the cardiac output remains static till the term. Cardiac output increases further during labor (+50%) and immediately following delivery (+70%) over the pre labor values.
